Merged_Standards.Integration: Linked with ISO 50001 (Performance evaluation) and BRSR Principle 7 (Transparency).
Merged_Standards.Example: Tracking monthly water-consumption and waste-generation trends to assess reduction progress.

Merged_Standards.Title: Internal audit
Merged_Standards.Purpose: Conduct periodic audits to ensure EMS conformity and identify improvement opportunities.
Merged_Standards.Evidence: Audit program, checklists, reports, corrective-action logs.
Merged_Standards.Integration: Aligned with ISO 19011 (Auditing) and ISO 9001 clause 9.2 (Internal audit).
Merged_Standards.Example: Quarterly internal EMS audits covering waste, emissions, and legal compliance.

Merged_Standards.Title: Management review
Merged_Standards.Purpose: Top management reviews EMS performance to ensure alignment with strategic direction and environmental policy.
Merged_Standards.Evidence: Review minutes, inputs and outputs, action-tracking sheets.
Merged_Standards.Integration: Connected to ISO 9001 clause 9.3 and supports ESG Governance review processes.
Merged_Standards.Example: Annual review discussing energy savings achieved and new sustainability targets.

Merged_Standards.Title: Nonconformity and corrective action
Merged_Standards.Purpose: Respond to environmental nonconformities, determine root causes, and implement corrective actions.
Merged_Standards.Evidence: Non-conformance reports, root-cause analyses, CAPA records.
Merged_Standards.Integration: Linked with ISO 9001 clause 10.2 and ISO 45001 clause 10.2.
Merged_Standards.Example: Investigating and correcting improper hazardous-waste labeling found during audit.

Merged_Standards.Title: Continual improvement
Merged_Standards.Purpose: Continually improve EMS effectiveness by enhancing environmental performance and achieving sustainability goals.
Merged_Standards.Evidence: Improvement logs, KPIs, project reports, performance-trend analysis.
Merged_Standards.Integration: Supports SDG 12 & 13 and aligns with the PDCA ‘Act’ phase.
Merged_Standards.Example: Replacing diesel generators with solar panels to reduce carbon emissions year-on-year.

Merged_Standards.title: Principles for Greenhouse Gas Accounting
Merged_Standards.purpose: Establish foundational principles that guide all greenhouse gas inventory work.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause defines the principles that organizations should apply when creating, managing, and reporting their GHG inventory. These include relevance, completeness, consistency, accuracy, and transparency. Applying these principles ensures that the GHG inventory is decision-useful and credible, and can support verification activities.
auditor_questions: How do you ensure completeness in your GHG inventory?
Are accounting principles documented and communicated?
What controls prevent errors in quantification?
examples: Using operational control principles consistently across all facilities.
Documenting rationale behind selected emission factors.

Merged_Standards.title: Organizational Boundaries
Merged_Standards.purpose: Define the parts of the organization included in the GHG inventory.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause requires organizations to decide which operations and entities fall within the boundary of the GHG inventory. Organizations must choose between the equity share, financial control, or operational control approach. Clear boundary definitions prevent double-counting and ensure alignment with corporate structures.
evidence: List of subsidiaries and joint ventures
auditor_questions: Which boundary approach have you selected and why?
How did you treat joint ventures or leased assets?
Is the boundary applied consistently year to year?
risks: Incorrect boundary selection causing omitted emissions
Inconsistency between financial and GHG boundaries
examples: Using operational control boundary for manufacturing sites while excluding minority-owned JV plants.
Including leased warehouses under operational control.

Merged_Standards.title: GHG Inventory Boundary – Emissions and Removals
Merged_Standards.purpose: Define which emission sources and sinks fall inside the inventory boundary.
Merged_Standards.summary: Organizations must identify and categorize emissions and removals as direct (Scope 1) or energy-indirect (Scope 2). This clause ensures clarity about what sources are included, such as stationary combustion, mobile emissions, process emissions, fugitive emissions, and carbon removals. A consistent boundary supports decision-usefulness of the data.
auditor_questions: How did you identify all relevant emission sources?
What approach was used for categorizing Scope 1 and Scope 2?
Were biogenic emissions treated separately?
examples: Stationary combustion boilers categorized under Scope 1.
Electricity consumption for HVAC counted under Scope 2.

Merged_Standards.title: Baseline (Reference) Year
Merged_Standards.purpose: Establish a reference year to measure progress against.
Merged_Standards.summary: The reference year serves as the benchmark for comparing future emissions or removals. Organizations must choose a year for which reliable data exists and document the rationale. Baseline adjustments may be required if there are structural changes, such as mergers, divestitures, or methodological improvements.
auditor_questions: Why was the chosen year selected as the baseline?
Have any recalculations been made to the baseline?
Do you maintain documentation of structural changes?
risks: Incorrect baseline causes misleading reduction claims
Failure to recalc baseline after acquisitions
Inaccurate data leading to incorrect reporting
examples: Choosing 2019 as baseline due to full data availability.
Recalculating baseline after acquiring new facilities.

Merged_Standards.title: Quantification of GHG Emissions and Removals
Merged_Standards.purpose: Provide a structured method to calculate emissions and removals.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause outlines how organizations should quantify emissions using activity data, emission factors, and appropriate methodologies. It requires separate quantification of fossil CO2, biogenic CO2, CH4, N2O, and other greenhouse gases. Organizations must apply accepted quantification approaches, maintain transparency, and use credible sources for emission factors.
auditor_questions: Which emission factors were used and why?
How do you maintain quality of activity data?
Were estimations applied for missing data?
risks: Incorrect factors lead to inaccurate emissions
examples: Using DEFRA 2024 factors for diesel combustion.
Estimating refrigerant leakage using mass balance.

Merged_Standards.title: Monitoring Requirements
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure consistent and reliable tracking of GHG emissions and removals over time.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause establishes the need for a structured monitoring plan that identifies what data will be monitored, how often, by whom, and with what tools or meters. Monitoring ensures that emissions and removals are tracked consistently and that any changes in operations or boundaries are captured accurately.
auditor_questions: Do you have a documented monitoring plan?
How frequently is each parameter monitored?
Are metering devices regularly calibrated?
risks: Unreliable metering leading to incorrect values
Lack of clarity on monitoring responsibilities
examples: Monthly monitoring of diesel consumption using fuel dip logs.
Continuous monitoring of natural gas flow using calibrated meters.

Merged_Standards.title: Data Quality Assurance and Control
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure data accuracy, completeness, and transparency through quality management practices.
Merged_Standards.summary: Organizations must implement QA/QC procedures to validate and verify data before it forms part of the GHG inventory. This includes cross-checking data sources, performing internal reviews, verifying meter readings, and documenting assumptions. Strong QA/QC builds confidence in reported emissions.
auditor_questions: What QA/QC checks do you perform on activity data?
How do you assure data accuracy from suppliers?
Are internal audits performed on GHG data?

ESG: BRSR - Accuracy & Reliability of Quantitative Metrics

examples: Cross-checking diesel purchase bills with generator operation logs.
Using automated scripts to flag abnormal readings.

Merged_Standards.title: GHG Inventory Documentation
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure that all methods, assumptions, and data sources are fully documented for transparency.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause requires organizations to maintain complete documentation supporting their GHG inventory. Documentation should describe boundaries, quantification methods, data sources, activity data, emission factors, QA/QC procedures, assumptions, and calculations. Proper documentation facilitates verification and long-term consistency.
auditor_questions: Is your GHG inventory fully documented?
Where are original data sources stored?
Have assumptions been recorded and justified?
examples: Maintaining a central GHG inventory folder with all calculation sheets.
Documenting the rationale for using a specific emission factor.

Merged_Standards.title: Internal Review of GHG Inventory
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure internal evaluation of data quality before external reporting.
Merged_Standards.summary: Organizations must perform internal reviews to assess whether the GHG inventory is complete, accurate, and follows defined methodologies. Reviews may include internal audits, management approvals, or cross-departmental verification. This ensures errors are detected early.
auditor_questions: How often are internal reviews performed?
Are findings tracked and closed with corrective actions?
Is top management involved in the review?
examples: Annual cross-functional review of GHG data.
Internal audit team checking emission factor sources.

Merged_Standards.title: Reporting Requirements
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure organizations provide transparent and complete disclosure of GHG emissions.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause outlines what information must be included in a GHG inventory report, such as boundary selection, methodologies, emission totals, removals, uncertainties, and any recalculations. Reporting must be clear, consistent, and suitable for stakeholders such as regulators, investors, or verifiers.
auditor_questions: Does your report include all required disclosures?
Are uncertainty and limitations discussed?
Did you recalculate prior-year data? If yes, why?

ESG: ESRS E1, GRI 305, BRSR Section C

examples: GHG report with facility-level breakdown of Scope 1 and 2.
Disclosing changes in organizational boundaries year-over-year.

Merged_Standards.title: Recalculation of Historical Emissions
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure consistency when structural, methodological, or data-related changes occur.
Merged_Standards.summary: Organizations must recalculate historical emissions when significant structural changes (acquisitions, divestitures), methodology changes, or major corrections occur. This preserves comparability of emissions over time and ensures trends reflect real performance changes.
auditor_questions: What triggers require baseline recalculations?
Did any structural changes occur this year?
How did recalculations impact reported emissions?
examples: Recalculating baseline after a 30% capacity expansion.
Adjusting historical emissions due to improved metering.

Merged_Standards.title: Support for Verification
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure GHG inventory information is sufficient for third-party verification.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause defines the documentation and transparency required to support independent verification. Organizations must provide verifiers with access to data sources, methodologies, assumptions, QA/QC processes, and facility information. High-quality documentation streamlines verification and improves credibility.
auditor_questions: Is all necessary documentation available for verification?
Do you maintain traceable data flows?
Are assumptions clearly justified?
examples: Providing verifiers with a complete GHG calculation workbook.
Maintaining facility-level source data archive.

Merged_Standards.title: Principles for GHG Projects
Merged_Standards.purpose: Define the principles that guide planning, implementing, and reporting GHG reduction or removal projects.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause outlines the foundational principles for designing GHG projects, including relevance, completeness, consistency, accuracy, transparency, and conservativeness. These ensure the project’s quantified reductions or removals are credible and suitable for verification. Conservativeness is emphasized to avoid overstating benefits.
auditor_questions: How are project principles embedded in project design?
What ensures conservativeness in quantification?
How do you maintain transparency across the project cycle?
risks: Insufficient transparency leading to verification failure
examples: Applying conservative emission factors when multiple options exist.
Documenting all assumptions used in baseline scenario selection.

Merged_Standards.title: Project Description and Objectives
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure clarity on project purpose, boundaries, and expected GHG outcomes.
Merged_Standards.summary: Organizations must clearly state the project's purpose, sources affected, technologies used, expected reductions or removals, and how the project aligns with broader climate goals. A well-defined project description helps structure the quantification, monitoring, and reporting steps.
auditor_questions: What GHG sources or sinks does the project impact?
What is the main emission reduction mechanism?
Are project objectives measurable and realistic?
risks: Unclear scope resulting in miscalculated reductions
Poorly defined boundaries causing leakage issues
examples: Replacing diesel generators with solar PV systems.
Capturing methane from wastewater treatment.

Merged_Standards.title: Project Boundary
Merged_Standards.purpose: Identify all relevant GHG sources, sinks, and reservoirs affected by the project.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause requires organizations to clearly determine the geographic, operational, and temporal boundaries for the GHG project. Boundaries include sources that increase or decrease emissions, as well as carbon stocks that may change due to the project. Proper boundary setting prevents double counting and ensures accurate quantification.
evidence: Land use or facility zoning records
auditor_questions: How were project boundaries established?
Which emission sources are included and excluded?
Are boundary decisions justified and documented?
risks: Boundary omissions leading to overstated reductions
examples: Including upstream emissions affected by fuel switching.
Defining forest plantation boundaries in a removal project.

Merged_Standards.title: Baseline Scenario Selection
Merged_Standards.purpose: Establish the scenario that would occur in the absence of the GHG project.
Merged_Standards.summary: The baseline scenario represents what emissions or removals would have been without the project. Organizations must identify all plausible alternatives, assess feasibility, and select the most credible baseline. Documenting assumptions, data sources, and justification is essential to ensure the baseline is realistic and conservative.
auditor_questions: How were baseline alternatives identified?
Why was the selected baseline chosen as most plausible?
What assumptions underpin baseline calculations?
risks: Inflated reductions due to unrealistic baseline
examples: Baseline: diesel boiler; project: natural gas boiler upgrade.
Baseline: open burning; project: methane capture and flaring.

Merged_Standards.title: Additionality Demonstration
Merged_Standards.purpose: Show that GHG reductions or removals are not ‘business as usual’.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause requires demonstrating that the project’s GHG impact would not have occurred without intentional project intervention. Additionality assessments typically consider regulatory requirements, financial viability, technological barriers, and common practice. Proving additionality is essential for generating credible reduction claims or offset credits.
auditor_questions: What criteria were used to determine additionality?
Is the project legally required?
Would the project be financially attractive without GHG benefits?
risks: Non-additional projects create invalid carbon credits
examples: Renewable energy project requiring carbon revenue to be viable.
Afforestation project facing significant financial or legal barriers.

Merged_Standards.title: Identification and Assessment of Leakage
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure all unintended increases in emissions outside the project boundary are identified and accounted for.
Merged_Standards.summary: Leakage refers to GHG emissions that occur outside the project boundary but are caused by project activities. This clause requires organizations to identify potential leakage sources, assess their likelihood, estimate magnitude, and incorporate them into net GHG benefits. Leakage assessment prevents overstating project effectiveness.
auditor_questions: What types of leakage were considered?
How did the project impact external systems or markets?
Was leakage quantified and included in net GHG reductions?
examples: Improved cookstove projects: fuelwood harvesting shifts to new areas.
Forest protection projects: deforestation moves to another region.

Merged_Standards.title: Permanence of GHG Reductions or Removals
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure long-term durability of GHG benefits generated by the project.
Merged_Standards.summary: Permanence refers to the risk that GHG reductions or removals may be reversed in the future. Organizations must assess permanence risks, such as natural disturbances, management failures, market shocks, or legal changes. Projects must apply risk mitigation measures and consider buffer reserves, insurance, or monitoring commitments.
auditor_questions: What risks could reverse the GHG benefits?
Is there a buffer or insurance mechanism?
How long will monitoring and reporting continue?
risks: Short-term credits with no long-term guarantees
examples: Forest removal projects implementing a 20-year monitoring plan.
Biogas projects ensuring long-term operational commitments.

Merged_Standards.title: Quantification of GHG Reductions or Removals
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure reductions and removals are quantified using transparent and credible methods.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause requires organizations to quantify project GHG benefits by comparing baseline emissions with project scenario emissions. Quantification must be based on accepted methods, credible emission factors, reliable activity data, and transparent assumptions. Net benefits must account for leakage and non-permanence risks.
auditor_questions: What calculation methods were used?
How were baseline and project emissions compared?
Were leakage and permanence accounted for?
examples: Comparing baseline diesel generator emissions vs. solar PV emissions.
Quantifying methane capture from landfill gas systems.

Merged_Standards.title: GHG Project Monitoring Plan
Merged_Standards.purpose: Provide a clear plan for tracking project performance and GHG outcomes.
Merged_Standards.summary: Organizations must create a detailed monitoring plan that specifies what parameters are measured, how often, using what tools, and by whom. Monitoring must align with quantification methods and ensure data integrity. The plan must address uncertainties and ensure verifiers can track data back to source documents.
auditor_questions: What parameters are monitored and why?
Are monitoring tools calibrated and traceable?
How is monitoring data validated?
risks: Inability to demonstrate real GHG performance
examples: Monitoring methane flow rate in a biodigester project.
Tracking electricity output from solar installations.

Merged_Standards.title: Data Management and Information Systems
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure systems are in place to manage, store, and protect project data.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause requires organizations to maintain structured data management systems to store activity data, emission factors, monitoring results, and calculations. Systems must ensure data accuracy, security, traceability, and accessibility for verification. Both digital and manual systems should include controls for consistency and integrity.
auditor_questions: How is project data stored and secured?
Are data changes tracked via version control?
What procedures ensure data integrity?
risks: Verification challenges due to missing evidence
examples: Using cloud-based systems with audit trail features.
Storing all raw meter readings in a central data archive.

Merged_Standards.title: GHG Project Reporting Requirements
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure transparent, complete, and accurate reporting of project outcomes.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause defines what must be included in a GHG project report. Required elements include project description, boundaries, baseline scenario, additionality demonstration, quantification methods, monitoring plan, emission reduction results, leakage assessment, uncertainty evaluation, and any limitations. Clear reporting enhances credibility and facilitates verification.
evidence: Summary tables of reductions or removals
auditor_questions: Does the project report include all required disclosures?
Are assumptions and uncertainties transparently documented?
How were monitoring results incorporated into the report?
examples: A GHG report summarizing methane capture and destruction efficiency.
A solar project report detailing emissions avoided vs. baseline grid emissions.

Merged_Standards.title: Disclosure of Assumptions, Uncertainty, and Method Limitations
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure transparency by documenting methodological choices and uncertainties.
Merged_Standards.summary: Projects must clearly disclose assumptions, calculation methods, emission factors, and uncertainties within both baseline and project scenarios. Assumptions must be defensible, realistic, and supported by evidence. Transparent disclosure ensures verifiers and stakeholders can assess project integrity.
auditor_questions: What assumptions underpin the baseline scenario?
How were uncertainties assessed?
Were methodological limitations clearly disclosed?
risks: Verification failures due to undisclosed assumptions
examples: Documenting assumptions about fuel quality variability.
Listing uncertainty ranges for direct measurement equipment.

Merged_Standards.title: Recalculation of Project Reductions
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure historical project results remain comparable when underlying conditions change.
Merged_Standards.summary: Organizations must recalculate previously reported reductions when key factors change, such as baseline updates, methodological changes, or discovery of errors. Recalculation ensures consistent performance tracking and prevents misleading emission reduction claims.
auditor_questions: What conditions trigger recalculation?
Were previous project years recalculated appropriately?
Has documentation been updated following recalculation?
examples: Recalculating historical results after updated grid emission factors.
Correcting past data due to improved metering in project systems.

Merged_Standards.title: Verification Support Documentation
Merged_Standards.purpose: Provide documentation sufficient for third-party verification of reductions or removals.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause requires organizations to maintain complete, organized, and traceable documentation to support verification. Records must include boundary definitions, baseline assessments, quantification spreadsheets, monitoring data, and QA/QC processes. Verifiers must be able to trace emissions data back to original sources.
auditor_questions: Is all documentation traceable and readily accessible?
Can verifiers reproduce emission calculations?
Have QA/QC processes been adequately documented?
risks: Loss of credibility for emission reduction claims
examples: Providing verifiers with time-stamped monitoring data.
Maintaining a version-controlled quantification model.

Merged_Standards.title: Roles, Responsibilities, and Competence
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure personnel involved in the project have appropriate skills, defined roles, and documented responsibilities.
Merged_Standards.summary: Organizations must assign clear responsibilities for project implementation, data management, monitoring, and reporting. Personnel must have adequate competence in GHG quantification, measurement, and documentation. Proper role definition improves reliability and reduces errors during the project lifecycle.
auditor_questions: Who is responsible for monitoring and quantification?
How is competence ensured for key roles?
Are responsibilities documented and communicated?
risks: Inadequate competence leading to calculation errors
Ambiguity in responsibilities causing data gaps
examples: Assigning monitoring duties to engineering teams with training.
Defining data management roles in the project management plan.

Merged_Standards.title: Principles for Verification and Validation
Merged_Standards.purpose: Define the fundamental principles that guide the verification and validation of GHG statements.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause establishes the core principles of GHG verification and validation, including relevance, completeness, consistency, accuracy, transparency, and independence. These principles ensure that verifier assessments are credible, impartial, and aligned with international assurance practices. They guide all stages of the verification process, from planning to issuing the final opinion.
auditor_questions: How are independence and impartiality ensured?
What principles guide the verification activities?
Are verification methods applied consistently?
examples: Verifier stating independence from the organization being reviewed.
Use of transparent methodologies to evaluate emission factors.

Merged_Standards.title: Validation Requirements
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure the evaluation of GHG project assumptions and plans BEFORE project implementation.
Merged_Standards.summary: Validation is a pre-implementation assessment that evaluates whether a GHG project is reasonable, well-designed, and capable of achieving projected emission reductions or removals. The verifier reviews baseline justification, additionality, methodologies, quantification approaches, and risk management strategies. Validation ensures the project framework is sound before reductions occur.
auditor_questions: Is the baseline scenario credible and justified?
Does the project meet additionality requirements?
Are monitoring methods clearly defined and feasible?
risks: Project fails to deliver expected reductions
Validation errors leading to later disputes
examples: Validating a renewable energy project’s baseline grid emission factor.
Reviewing afforestation project permanence and leakage risks.

Merged_Standards.title: Verification Requirements
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure objective and evidence-based evaluation of GHG statements after quantification.
Merged_Standards.summary: Verification assesses whether a GHG statement is complete, accurate, and prepared according to relevant standards or methodologies. This includes reviewing data quality, quantification methods, boundary definitions, assumptions, and internal controls. Verification provides assurance that reported emissions or reductions are credible and traceable.
auditor_questions: Are emissions quantification methods appropriate?
Can data be traced back to original records?
Are inconsistencies or anomalies adequately explained?
examples: Verifier identifying inconsistencies in electricity consumption data.
Cross-checking diesel usage with procurement records.

Merged_Standards.title: Levels of Assurance
Merged_Standards.purpose: Define the degree of confidence required in verification conclusions.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause establishes two assurance levels for GHG verification: reasonable assurance and limited assurance. Reasonable assurance requires more extensive evidence collection, deeper testing, and stronger support for conclusions. Limited assurance requires fewer procedures but still requires credible and traceable information. Organizations must select the level that aligns with stakeholder requirements.
auditor_questions: What level of assurance was selected and why?
Are verification procedures consistent with the selected assurance level?
Is there sufficient evidence to support the conclusion?
examples: Large corporates choosing reasonable assurance for Scope 1/2.
Small organizations obtaining limited assurance for annual reporting.

Merged_Standards.title: Materiality
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure the verifier evaluates the significance of errors and omissions.
Merged_Standards.summary: Materiality determines whether an error or omission could influence the decisions of report users. Verifiers must establish a materiality threshold and assess whether inaccuracies exceed this threshold. Materiality is both quantitative and qualitative, and is essential for deciding verification conclusions.
auditor_questions: What materiality threshold was applied?
Were both qualitative and quantitative factors considered?
Did identified errors exceed the threshold?
examples: Setting a 5% materiality threshold for an inventory totaling 100,000 tCO2e.
Treating a small error as material due to reputational implications.

Merged_Standards.title: Verification/Validation Planning
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure that verification and validation activities are strategically planned and based on project or inventory characteristics.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause requires verifiers to prepare a verification plan that outlines objectives, scope, criteria, assurance level, risks, team resources, and timelines. Planning ensures that verification work is aligned with the complexity of the GHG statement and focuses on areas with higher risk of misstatement. A well-developed plan forms the backbone of a structured verification process.
auditor_questions: Does the plan reflect project or inventory complexity?
Were high-risk areas prioritized?
Is the scope clearly defined and agreed upon?
risks: Insufficient planning may miss critical issues
Misalignment between scope and verification activities
examples: Developing a plan emphasizing fuel combustion and refrigerant use due to high emissions.
Defining sampling strategy based on identified risks.

Merged_Standards.title: GHG Risk Assessment
Merged_Standards.purpose: Identify risks that could cause material misstatements in the GHG statement.
Merged_Standards.summary: Verifiers must evaluate inherent risks such as data quality issues, methodological weaknesses, boundary errors, or operational inconsistencies. The risk assessment informs sampling, testing depth, and evidence-gathering strategies. An effective risk analysis helps focus verification on the most critical elements of the GHG statement.
auditor_questions: What major risks were identified?
How were risks incorporated into the verification strategy?
Are risks reassessed during the verification process?
risks: Inaccurate assurance conclusion due to poor risk evaluation
Unexpected findings late in the verification process
examples: Identifying high uncertainty in refrigerant fugitive emissions.
Flagging incomplete energy data as a significant risk.

Merged_Standards.title: Evidence-Gathering Procedures
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure verification conclusions are supported by sufficient, appropriate evidence.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause requires verifiers to gather evidence through interviews, document reviews, data reconciliation, recalculations, and site visits when required. Evidence must be reliable, traceable, and adequate to support the level of assurance. Procedures must be adjusted based on the complexity and risks of the GHG statement.
auditor_questions: Were evidence-gathering procedures adequate for the assurance level?
Can all data be traced back to original sources?
Were interviews conducted with responsible personnel?
risks: Insufficient evidence leading to incorrect conclusions
examples: Cross-checking diesel consumption with ERP purchase records.
Conducting site visits to confirm meter installation and calibration.

Merged_Standards.title: Sampling Strategies
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure appropriate sampling approaches are used for data testing to support verification conclusions.
Merged_Standards.summary: Verifiers must design sampling plans based on identified risks, data volume, variability, and complexity. Sampling may be statistical or judgment-based. Proper sampling ensures efficient testing while maintaining confidence that material misstatements will be detected.
auditor_questions: How was the sampling strategy determined?
Is the sample size adequate for materiality thresholds?
Were high-risk data points prioritized?
risks: Undetected errors due to inadequate sampling
examples: Sampling electricity bills from each quarter across multiple facilities.
Targeting fuel consumption data from equipment with historically high variance.

Merged_Standards.title: Evaluation of GHG Information
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure verifiers evaluate data accuracy, consistency, and alignment with applicable methodologies.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause requires verifiers to review all gathered evidence, recalculate emission estimates, assess boundary definitions, evaluate methodologies, and confirm that assumptions are reasonable. Verifiers must determine whether the GHG statement aligns with the selected standard or program requirements.
auditor_questions: Does the GHG statement follow required standards?
Were all emission sources evaluated for accuracy?
Are methodologies consistent with accepted practices?
risks: Misinterpretation of emission sources or boundaries
examples: Recalculating Scope 1 emissions to confirm accuracy.
Evaluating appropriateness of emission factors used.

Merged_Standards.title: Addressing Nonconformities and Issues
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure verifiers identify, communicate, and follow up on discrepancies or errors in GHG statements.
Merged_Standards.summary: Verifiers must document all nonconformities, categorize them as material or immaterial, communicate findings to the client, and obtain corrective actions. If material nonconformities remain uncorrected, the verifier may need to modify or withhold a verification opinion.
auditor_questions: Were nonconformities documented clearly?
Did the organization provide sufficient corrective action?
Are remaining issues material?
examples: Organization updating emission factors after nonconformity.
Verifier issuing a modified opinion due to unresolved data gaps.

Merged_Standards.title: Forming Verification or Validation Conclusions
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure verifiers issue a clear, justified, and evidence-based conclusion.
Merged_Standards.summary: Based on all gathered evidence, verifiers must form a conclusion about whether the GHG statement is free from material misstatement. The conclusion must reflect the assurance level, materiality threshold, scope, and limitations. Conclusions may include unmodified opinions, modified opinions, or disclaimers if evidence is insufficient.
auditor_questions: Does the conclusion reflect all evidence gathered?
Are there limitations affecting the opinion?
Is the assurance level clearly stated?
examples: Verifiers issuing a reasonable assurance opinion for a complete Scope 1/2 inventory.
Providing a qualified opinion due to missing activity data.

Merged_Standards.title: Verification and Validation Statement Requirements
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure verifiers issue transparent, complete, and accurate statements after completing verification or validation.
Merged_Standards.summary: This clause outlines what must be included in a verification or validation statement. Required elements typically include the scope, criteria used, level of assurance, summary of verification procedures, materiality threshold, conclusions, limitations, and any unresolved nonconformities. Clear statements ensure stakeholders understand what was evaluated and the confidence level of the results.
auditor_questions: Does the statement include all mandatory elements?
Are limitations clearly described?
Does the conclusion accurately reflect verification evidence?
examples: A verification statement specifying reasonable assurance for Scope 1 & 2 data.
A validation statement disclosing methodological limitations.

Merged_Standards.title: Content of Validation or Verification Report
Merged_Standards.purpose: Ensure full documentation of verification or validation activities in a detailed report.
Merged_Standards.summary: In addition to the public verification statement, verifiers must prepare a comprehensive report documenting all activities performed, evidence collected, sampling procedures, risks, and findings. This report is typically shared with the client and may be reviewed by accreditation bodies. It supports transparency and strengthens verification credibility.
auditor_questions: Does the report document all verification steps?
